result.title: Analysis of Ranking Contests
result.content:
Ranking contests is critically important to evaluate the individual performance of participants which is helpful in team selection.

This year, we will be running 5 ranking contests that cover most of the topics and problems categories that appear in the national and regional contests.

Every participant will get a rating. The overall rating is the arithmetic mean of all contest ratings. Contest rating depends on both the number of problems solved and the contest rank. Formally:

where:

  • solved is the number of problems solved by the contestant.
  • maxSolved is the number of problems solved by the first rank.
  • n is the maximum of 50 and the number of contestants in the contest.

Obviously, the first rank get a score of 200 points. You can find your rating here.

For a team to perform well in a contest, they must take care of the following points:

  • Individual performance and experience.
  • Contest strategy.
  • Team chemistry.

Individual performance and experience

This is the building block for the team. Experienced contestants always make a good team. And this is the main point that you get after analyzing the ranking contests. With ranking contests, you can evaluate:

  • Speed: which indicates

    1. experience: dividing the problem to subtasks with a previous experience with these subtasks.
    2. problem-solving skills: coming up with creative solutions for unseen problems.
    3. coding skills: writing fast efficient bug-free code.

  • Code Cleanness: which is an important point for a team, as you might need to quickly understand and debug your teammate's code.

  • Optimality: contestants who always try to write the optimal solution (not any solution that will pass) are more probable to solve harder problems, because at every practice problem, they get the maximum benefit from it.

  • Contest Mentality: how contestants perform in a contest environment. For example, how they behave when they get a WA for a problem, can they move on to another problem? do they make too many submissions?). This point is better evaluated with trial team contests.

  • Experience: with the ability to solve problems on a specific topic. When all contests end, this blog will be updated with tags for problems and estimated difficulty.

Contest Strategy

How the team attack the problem set and manage their time efficiently is essential to solve the maximum number of reachable problems during contest time. Generally, the strategy for an individual contest is different from that of a team contest. Once a team is formed, they start to develop a strategy for team contests. We will talk about this point later.

Team Chemistry

Though individual performance is a clear logical parameter in team selection, one must keep in mind that not all people can get along with each other. That is because:

  • People have different mindsets. You are going to discuss problems with your teammates, so you should be able to understand each others' ideas.
  • People don't feel comfortable with everyone. You don't have to force yourself accept everyone, so pick teammates who you can enjoy a five-hour contest with them.

How to make a team?

  • When the ranking contests finish, analyze them based on the points mentioned above.
  • Keep in mind that some points can developed later such as experience with topics, contest strategy and others (depending on how patient is you to help your teammates improve their weaknesses).
  • Don't make the team blindly and pick your friends.
  • Make individual performance your first and main parameter for selection.
  • Do many trial team contests to make sure that you can get along with the teammates you selected. You may want to try different team combinations.
